title: Salt That Bleeds

quest_giver.name: Matron Selde Karst
quest_giver.affiliation: Salt Factors League at the Salt Crown Exchange

description: The wind-bells upon the Salt Crown Exchange sing a thin arithmetic of weather and warning, and beneath that silver ring the traders draw their oaths in chalk like sailors plotting shoals on a tide-wet deck. Confidence is a tide too, and someone has taught it to ebb by the fistful: counterfeit salt bricks have passed the witness circle and left chalky rings like dried tears upon the scales. Floor Marshal Hesk, a veteran of brine and ledger, swears his stamps are true and his seals unbroken, yet a missing mark whispers otherwise in corridors that taste of old tears and ink. Kezra Thorneglass hears a remembered pattern in the wind-bells—a cadence the Night Cartographers stitch into their ciphered maps—and knows that truth has been shaved thin and pressed against salt until the city’s tongue cannot tell the difference. The vault tiers hum with quiet fear as the bricks sit like white tombstones, and a rumor runs to the Ember Gate slag cellars where old coin-dies sleep in warm ash, teeth closed around ghostly faces and forgotten contracts. To steady the Exchange without breaking it, the investigation must weigh three lots, question hands that swear they do not tremble, follow whispers into furnace-dark, and return with a method laid bare that cools the crowd rather than sets it to riot. If the city’s lifeblood is threefold—silk, salt, and iron—then this night is an incision, and the only mercy is a clean cut, seen and acknowledged by all.
objectives: Inspect three lots of salt bricks and compare grain, ring, and scratch to known standards, tasting for brine truth while observing the faint chalk-cry each leaves upon the scales.
Interview Floor Marshal Hesk and two inspectors; verify stamp custody and nightly seals from bell to bell, and reconcile their witness logs with lantern-time in the vault corridors.
Track rumors through the Ember Gate to the slag cellars, locate a forgotten coin-mold among warm ash and slag, and compare its die marks and pressure-song to the counterfeit stamp’s bite.
Report to the Exchange on the forgery’s method with language that steadies prices rather than panics them, easing guild tempers without lighting a tariff war.

dialogue.speaker: Matron Selde Karst
dialogue.lines: You stand in a hall where salt is memory made brick, and memory is credit made breath, Kezra Thorneglass. I have weighed you as carefully as any tiered pallet, and I find no hollow under your voice when it speaks for a public trust. My rivals would buy fear by the wagon-load if I let these rumors stand, and then sell back calm by the pinch until the city drinks brine for supper. I do not ask you to lean the beam for me; I ask you to bind the truth to a weight, and let it fall where it will be seen and believed. Bring me a method I can show in daylight, a fault named so plainly even a hungry clerk will nod and say, yes, that is where the coin bit the salt.

dialogue.speaker: Floor Marshal Hesk
dialogue.lines: These vaults have heard my whistle at dawn and my counting at dusk for twelve straight years, and not once have I let a false brick kiss the witness sand without my shame scorching me awake. Yet now the sand bears rings like old tears and whispers run the rafters that my stamp has gone queer, and I would sooner drown in brine than be made a fool by a liar with a ruler. I keep the custody chain tighter than a diver’s lungs, lock to lock, bell to bell, ledger to ledger, and still some thin hand seems to have slipped a ghost through. Inspector Lysa Quill swears her night-seal held and her memory lantern burned steady; Journeyman Dred says the stamp sings true in his palm, but I hear a sour note that was not there last season. If you can prise the false note from this chorus, name it, and teach it to the bells so they ring it out, I’ll gladly set my hand in the brine and leave it there for the city to judge.

dialogue.speaker: Yael Emberkeel
dialogue.lines: Slag remembers the heat of lies longer than skin does, and old dies keep their bite like a widow minds a name. Down in the cellars, ash muffles footfall and memory both, and there’s a mold or two that never should have pressed metal, much less kissed a king’s face. If someone has taught a stamp to counterfeit the truth upon salt, they learned it where pressure speaks louder than witness and heat turns oaths to glass. Walk careful near the old coin-ghosts, Kezra; they have a way of asking you to measure yourself against the weight of what you think you know. Bring a steady lantern and a scarf for your breath, for some memories down there try to crawl into your throat and talk in your voice.

dialogue.speaker: Sera Verrin
dialogue.lines: Cargo is coin in a box, but confidence is coin in the air, and the Exchange trades both every breath it takes. Restore the second, and the first will stroll back on its own legs, head high, as if it had never wandered. You are adept at setting a fingertip on the scale to balance, not to cheat, and even that lightest touch can be the difference between a riot and a bow. I will not tell you what you ought to find, but I will tell you this: if your truth steadies the measure, the Hall of Shares will remember the steadier. Help us bring the story to heel without breaking its spine, and your name will be on lips when the city sets its next season of measures.

dialogue.speaker: Kezra Thorneglass
dialogue.lines: I will read the mark without letting it own the page, and I will test each ring until it sings or cracks. If a stamp bears a song, the wind-bells will remember its throat, and I will hum it back until the liar flinches. Where a shadow took a die into their hand, I will hold a lantern close enough to show the scar without setting tinder alight. I am bound by a thorn on my tongue to speak for the city’s good, and I know the cost of a word that tips a market the wrong way. Give me access to your ledgers and your silence until the telling is ready, and I will return with a method named, a culprit traced, and a calm that can be purchased without blood.

choices.title: Ring the bells with the cipher and expose the method publicly
choices.text: You gather a witness circle at high noon in the Exchange, when the sand-pit is a bright eye and every factor watches to see what it will blink. With Matron Selde and Floor Marshal Hesk standing opposite like anchors, you tune your mnemonic lantern to the wind-bells and hum the Night Cartographers’ cadence until the bells answer with that telltale pattern. You lay three bricks upon the sand—true, true, and false—and score each with the suspect stamp so the grain sings under your glass shard’s reflection. The crowd leans in as you show how the counterfeit bite leaves a feathered stress on the edge and how a chalk ring pools around it like old grief, a flaw learned in furnace-dark rather than born in flats under open sky. You name the technique without naming the hands, explaining pressure, heat, and the use of an illicit die found in slag cellars, and you seal the demonstration by inviting any guild to repeat it in your presence before the bells.
choices.outcome: The Exchange inhales as one and then exhales a measured breath, and prices steady like a boat settling after a wake. Matron Selde publicly thanks you without claiming you, and her rivals cannot accuse her of theater because the bells themselves answered your cadence. The Night Cartographers feel the sting of a chord played in daylight and pull three threads from Thornspire that night, leaving rumors like cut rope ends. Floor Marshal Hesk’s reputation is scuffed but not broken; he survives on the dignity of having stood beside the proof rather than in its way. Your name gains weight with the Hall of Shares and the common crowd alike, but a quiet note arrives at dusk: someone asks where you learned to make bells sing secrets, and their ink smells faintly of reed and midnight.

choices.title: Quiet audit, sacred sealing, and a calm report to avoid panic
choices.text: You refuse the stage and ask for a night under lanterns with ledgers, seals, and a pair of neutral oath-readers from the Order of the Black Thistle. In the cool of the vaults, Sister Meret pricks tongues and lays thistle-wreath penances nearby, and the taste of iron keeps everyone’s voices honest. You walk the custody chain bell by bell, matching ink strokes to breath rhythms and stamp to seal until the false interval reveals itself like a skipped heartbeat. Where the counterfeit die bit, you have Yael Emberkeel’s soot-sketched comparison ready, and her craft’s authority binds the finding like a rivet. By dawn you compose a report that names the method, prescribes a new seal sequence, and recommends double-witness assays for a fortnight, and you deliver it to the Exchange before the sand-pit wakes.
choices.outcome: No riot blooms, and the morning contracts trace sober circles instead of jagged spirals, though a few hands tremble less than they did yesterday. The Order claims small credit for the calm and, in exchange for your discretion, agrees to sanctify the new custody rite with a public blessing that costs no faction face. Matron Selde honors your restraint with coin and quiet favor, and Sera Verrin sends a courteous note layered with meanings you choose not to answer. The Night Cartographers hear that the melody of their cipher has been recognized and altered in the bells; they retreat to compose a new key rather than confront you now. Your standing with riverfolk and chapels rises for having mended a leak without calling a flood, and future doors in quiet corridors open when you pass.

choices.title: Set a forge-bait in the slag cellars and catch the counterfeiter’s hand
choices.text: With Yael Emberkeel’s leave, you shape a decoy die from soft iron and let word leak along the under-docks that an old prince’s mold hums again. You lace the slag paths with lantern cues and wrap your hush-silk scarf about your throat until your breath is a whisper the ash cannot find. When the forger comes—a careful soul in salt-stained gloves and a Night Cartographer’s habit of counting heartbeats—you let them press the bait and watch the feathered stress bloom, matching the wound seen in the Exchange. You speak softly from the dark, offering them a way to unburden a craft gone sour without the chains and a lesson in how to sing a stamp true if they will name their buyer. The ash shifts like a cat around your ankles as their story spills, each sentence a glowing seam that maps the path from flats to vault.
choices.outcome: You take the hand, not the head, and Thornspire notices the difference even if its ledgers do not show it. The forger gives up a route of favors measured by the ell that leads to a small Cartographer node on the Scribes’ Stair, and a die-maker in the Ember ward who wanted to hear his tools praised again. Yael Emberkeel’s name grows in the telling as the smith who helped trap a counterfeit bite without burning a life, and the Ferrum Collegium answers by tightening their own cellar locks. Matron Selde accepts a quiet list of complicities and chooses three to prosecute and three to bind with debt, a cruel mercy that keeps prices from spiking. The Night Cartographers mark you as a negotiator who can break a hand and leave a bridge standing, and they begin to court you with maps written in apologies and almost-truths.

choices.title: Leverage with Sera Verrin to stage a confidence play
choices.text: You approach Sera Verrin with a proposal dressed in measured honesty: you will reveal the forgery’s method in a controlled setting where House Verrin’s witnesses can corroborate without seeming to own the truth. Together you choreograph a demonstration in which she asks pointed questions that you answer with patient craft, letting the audience discover the deceit as if they themselves were clever. You ensure Floor Marshal Hesk and Matron Selde stand within the witness circle to lend gravity, and you secure a promise that no tariff change will be announced within the hour of revelation. When the bells ring the Cartographer cadence, you translate it into plain speech and show how a die’s feathered stress betrays a false bite, then you set a new baseline assay that any honest trader can repeat with glass and light. The crowd leaves not with scandal but with a tool—and a memory that House Verrin and Kezra Thorneglass gave it to them as a public good.
choices.outcome: Confidence returns by theater’s gentle hand rather than cudgel, and the market closes higher with fewer bent quills in the sand. House Verrin pockets a dividend of goodwill and uses it to argue for a modest reform of witness circles, and your name is spoken kindly in their manse for a season. Matron Selde dislikes sharing the stage but cannot refute the clean lift in prices, and she pays your fee with salted grace and a look that promises future debate. The Riverlight Pilots eye the alliance warily, muttering that scales balanced in parlors often bite the hands that row, and Olan Vetch advises you to watch the line between steadier and puppet. The Night Cartographers judge you a performer of truths and decide you must have a private map they have not seen; they begin to look for it under your lantern light and in your friends’ footsteps.

rewards.description: Exchange credit chit redeemable for travel provisions and small fees, its edges salted to resist damp and honored at most stalls that breathe the Exchange’s air.
Permission to observe future purity assays in the Salt Crown Exchange, granting escorted access to commodity halls and witness circles when assays are performed.
A bell-charm tuned to the wind-bell cipher that rings in subtle patterns when code is near, a pocket-sized sentinel that remembers the cadence you taught the air.
